rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Photochemical transformations of 6-formyl testosterone methyl enolether acetate, and its semicarbazne and oxime derivatives : some chemical constituents of c. parapsilosis and c. albicans
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Photochemical transformations have now been known to occur for over half a century since the time when sunlight was first used as a source of irradiation. Many reviews have been published since, covering many aspects of the subject(l-7). [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cardiac output during maximal exercise
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The view that cardiac output is the prime determinant of maximal oxygen intake has been discussed in the medical literature for some time (13, 61). The proposition was challenged by subsequent investigators (7, 30, 82) who, in agreement with Bock et al (23), claimed that 'peripheral factors' in terms of local blood flow and various changes at the muscular site were limiting maximal oxygen intake. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An evaluation of the significance of the Commonwealth preferential system for the economies of the Commonwealth Caribbean
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Commonwealth Preferential System is a discriminatory trading arrangement, governing trade among the territories of the British Commonwealth, which favours goods of Commonwealth origin through tariff preferences ( relatively low import duties), and in some cases, quotas and negotiated price schemes. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Double majority: concept, practice and negotiations, 1840-1848
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The phrase 'the system of the double majority' is a familiar one in Canadian histroriography. Despite this, double majority has never had a single study devoted it. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Synthesis of complex carbohydrates in the golgi region of secretory cells
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In 1891, 7 years before Camillo Golgi discovered his famous apparatus, Ramon y Cajal experienced one of his "most deplorable disappointments". While manipulating heavy metal impregnation techniques, he happened to immerse pieces of rat cerebrum in a potassium bichromate-gold chloride solution, and saw a selective reduction of gold salt in an intracellular apparatus, then unknown. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Immunofluorescent studies on pituitary
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The word "Pituitary" is derived from the Greek - pituita, meaning mucus or phlegm (1). In Galenic times (131 - 200 A.D.), it was thought that a by-product of animal spirits passed through this small body and filtered down through cribriform plate into the nose. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Attitudes toward fee-paying and non-fee paying clients
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This study focused on social caseworkers' attitudes toward fee-paying and non-fee-paying clients. The questions centred on (1) caseworkers' attitudes toward fee-paying and non-fee-paying clients; (2) how these attitudes were affected by (a) other attributes of the clients, (b) background experience of the caseworkers, and (c) workers' attitudes toward fee-charging. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Social Work

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Glacial geomorphology of the Churchill Falls area, Labrador
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Churchill Falls are a second Niagara. They are situated in the interior of Labrador, about 200 miles from the nearest point of the open Atlantic coast, and about 225 miles north of the Gulf of St.Lawrence (figure 1-1). [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Phospholipid metabolism in brain in vitro
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is only in the last two decades that the metabolic origin and function of phospholipids have lost some of their mystery. Thudichum (1, 2) reported in the 1880's the occurrence of lipid-associated phosphorus, and later studies only succeeded in establishing the general importance of this class of lipids as constituents of tissues. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Interfacial energy effects in metals
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: An interface can be defined as a bounding surface across which there is a discontinuity of some kind. Such discontinuities need not be abrupt, but may be in the form of a transition zone, so that interfaces may or may not have a thickness. Because of disturbances and irregularities at the interface, atoms there are in a state of higher energy than are the atoms in the homogeneous bulk. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Metallurgical Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The role of sex education in the schools
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The term sex education is one which has been and continues to be used in many different contexts. Few if any definitions of sex education convey a standard meaning of the term. Sex education can imply instruction and training offered to young children, adolescents, or adults. It may be given in the home, by the parents, at school, at church, or by scouting or youth oriented groups. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sex instruction
Education

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Metabolism of ribonucleic acid in rat brain in vitro
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The investigations reported in this thesis are concerned with the synthesis of ribonucleic acid in rat brain cortex slices. In an attempt to correlate the metabolism of RNA in vitro with the functioning of the brain in situ, brain slices were stimulated by changes in the concentrations of cations in the incubation medium as well as by the application of electrical pulses. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Lower Yuna river basin domincan republic restraints on agricultural development posed by physical and land tenure problems
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The findings of this study are primarily based upon fieldwork, for the reason that only scanty written sources exist on the Lower Yuna. This dearth of background information on which to build sometimes results in an unsophisticated level of treatment and has made necessary the inclusion of substantial descriptive and explanatory material in the form of expanded footnotes. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Mitotic activity in the epithelium of the caput epididymis of young and old adult rats
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During adult life many though not all tissues of the rat continue to increase in size through cellular proliferation. For example, neurones show no evidence of mitoses whereas in the intestine mitotic activity of the lining epithelium is so great that the epithelial cell population is replaced once in three days. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Anatomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Metabolism of adenine nucleotides in human erythrocytes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is now generally accepted that the clinical efficacy of the preserved blood specimens is determined by the metabolic status of the erythrocytes. The changes that occur in the metabolic potential of the cells during the storage period influence greatly the viability of the cells, that is, the ability of the cells to remain in the circulation on transfusion. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The use of left heart bypass in cardiogenic shock in dogs
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Cardiogenic shock is the syndrome of acute circulatory collapse secondary to myocardia1 infarction. This type of shock is responsible for much of the overall mortality of acute coronary artery occlusion especially in the younger age group. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Paired-associate learning in deaf and hearing children
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A number of experiments have indicated that the deaf do not perform as well as the hearing in various visual memory and learning situations (Pintner and Paterson, 1916, 1917; Blair, 1957; Hartman and Elliott, 1965). Pintner and Paterson (1916, 1917) suggested that the inability of deaf subjects to engage in verbalizations and thereby provide themselves with auditory imagery accounts for this deficit. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Psychology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Adrenal steroid production and function in normal rats and in rats bearing bilaterally regenerated adrenal glands
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The ability of sectioned rat adrenals to respond to ACTH in vitro has been demonstrated (1,2,3) but a detailed time study to show the degree and maintenance of this response over a prolonged period has not been carried out. The first aim of this study was to investigate the conditions necessary for the maintenance of increased corticosteroidogenesis, in response to ACTH, over an incubation period of 10 hours. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Boys’ Clubs in Canada : operational problems identified and ranked
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This study focuses on the operational problems of Boys' Clubs in Canada as perceived by the administrative staff at the local, regional and national levels. Up to the present stage in the development of the Boys' Club movement, a systematic study of this nature has not previously been attempted. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Social Work

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Comparative studies of adrenal steroid biosynthesis in various species
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Preliminary studies on the biosynthesis of steroids by the rat adrenal using radioactive precursors have revealed that under 'in vitro' conditions progesterone-4-14c is transformed to at least 23 labeled products (1,2). Out of these only 8 have been identified. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Investigative Medicine

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The use of low frequency residual hearing in profoundly deaf children
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Up to the present time it has been customary for hearing aids to reproduce approximately the same range of frequencies as the telephone (300 - 3000 eps). The aim of this investigation was to determine whether additional low frequency amplification, achieved by the provision of hearing aide with a frequency range from 80 - 3000 eps, would contribute significantly to the audition of speech among children with low-tone residual hearing. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Human Communications Disorders

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of radar echo patches in summer storms
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Plots of areal coverage as a function of height and intensity have been made for 17 radar echo patches all smaller than 1300 nmi.^2, that were recorded on the constant altitude maps of the 3-cm McGill radar. From these plots, vertical profiles of flux and density of precipitation have been obtained. The profiles generally showed maximum values aloft. The maxima were usually observed to descend or remain at one level. Occasions of ascent were less frequent. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Storms
Meteorology
Radar meteorology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the chemical nature of the binding of 'bound acetylcholine' in rat brain
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The theory of synaptic transmission in the nervous system describes the propagation of nerve impulses through a network of "neurones". "Neurones" was used by Waldeyer (1891) to describe the nerve cells which includes the nucleated cell body as weil as ali of its processes. Nerve cells are separated from but intermingled with its neighbors. There is no continuity between adjacent processes as was previously believed. lnstead, a synapse (Sherrington, 1897) was thought to be present at the point of contact between any two links in the chain of cells (Schafer, 1900). [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry
